title: So much for new Labor!
text:
Since May 18, the Labor Party under Anthony Albanese has begun to move away from Bill Shorten’s big-taxing, big-spending, politics-of-envy agenda. The waving-through of the free trade agreements showed signs of a new pro-reform direction. But old political habits die hard.

On the day of Mr Albanese’s "headland" speech on jobs, a Labor frontbencher preferred to flick the switch back to reflexive populism. In response to Liberal senator Dean Smith’s opinion article in yesterday’s The Australian Financial Review endorsing the NSW government’s plan for productivity-enhancing tax reform that aims to promote more higher-paying jobs, Labor’s shadow treasurer Jim Chalmers tweeted: “Says it all: when wages are stagnant, pensions and super are a risk, and multinationals aren’t paying their fair share, Liberals now want to jack up the GST so that those families, workers and pensioners who can least afford it are hit the hardest.” Dr Chalmer’s cheap-shot cheer chasing is the kind of political opportunism that has done so much damage to the national reform conversation in the past decade. And Scott Morrison played his role in ruling it all out. The reforming spirit of the Hawke-Keating and Howard-Costello governments seems ever more distant.
description: The reforming spirit of the 1980s and '90s is not found in today's policy wasteland of populist politics.
